abstract_summ: In addition, transmission heterogeneity usually envokes super spreading events (SSEs) where certain individuals infect large numbers of secondary cases.Here, we present a compartmental (SEIR) epidemiological model framework for estimating transmission parameters from multiple imperfectly observed data streams, including reported cases, deaths, and mobile phone-based mobility that incorporates individual-level heterogeneity in transmission using previous estimates for SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2.Our results highlighted more efforts are needed to verify the transmission heterogeneity of COVID-19 in other populations and its contributing factors.While they are rare, superspreading events (SSEs), wherein a few primary cases infect an extraordinarily large number of secondary cases, are recognized as a prominent determinant of aggregate infection rates (R0).Utilizing a heterogeneous transmission model based on branching process along with a negative binomial offspring distribution, we estimated the reproductive number R and the dispersion parameter k which characterized the transmission potential and heterogeneity, respectively.
title_summ: Significance of super spreader events in COVID-19.Power Laws in Superspreading Events: Evidence from Coronavirus Outbreaks and Implications for SIR ModelsCharacterizing super-spreading events and age-specific infectivity of COVID-19 transmission in Georgia, USASpatial Network based model forecasting transmission and control of COVID-19Evaluating transmission heterogeneity and super-spreading event of COVID-19 in a metropolis of ChinaLived population density and the spread of COVID-19Stochasticity and heterogeneity in the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2Spatiotemporal dynamics in demography-sensitive disease transmission: COVID-19 spread in NY as a case studyInferring super-spreading from transmission clusters of COVID-19 in Hong Kong, Japan and SingaporeDo superspreaders generate new superspreaders?a hypothesis to explain the propagation pattern of COVID-19Evaluating Transmission Heterogeneity and Super-Spreading Event of COVID-19 in a Metropolis of ChinaChopping the tail: how preventing superspreading can help to maintain COVID-19 control
title_abstract_phrases: In addition, transmission heterogeneity usually envokes super spreading events (SSEs) where certain individuals infect large numbers of secondary cases.Here, we present a compartmental (SEIR) epidemiological model framework for estimating transmission parameters from multiple imperfectly observed data streams, including reported cases, deaths, and mobile phone-based mobility that incorporates individual-level heterogeneity in transmission using previous estimates for SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2.Here, we describe the potential types of SSEs, how they influence transmission, and give recommendations for control of SARS-CoV-2.Spatiotemporal dynamics in demography-sensitive disease transmission: COVID-19 spread in NY as a case studyThe rapid transmission of the highly contagious novel coronavirus has been represented through several data-guided approaches across targeted geographies, in an attempt to understand when the pandemic will be under control and imposed lockdown measures can be relaxed.Evaluating transmission heterogeneity and super-spreading event of COVID-19 in a metropolis of ChinaBackground: COVID-19 caused rapid mass infection worldwide.More efforts are needed to verify the transmission heterogeneity of COVID-19 in other populations and its contributing factors, which is important for developing targeted measures to curb the pandemic.
